title: Extension of the mitochondria dysfunction hypothesis of metabolic syndrome to atherosclerosis with emphasis on the endocrine-disrupting chemicals and biophysical laws.

theories.name: Mitochondrial Dysfunction Theory of Metabolic Syndrome and Atherosclerosis
theories.evidence: The paper presents extensive literature citations including epidemiological associations between EDC exposure and metabolic syndrome/atherosclerosis, experimental data on mitochondrial toxicity of POPs, animal studies showing vascular inflammation induced by toxins, clinical trial data questioning efficacy of revascularization, and biophysical modeling applying metabolic scaling and fractal physiology principles.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory meets all core criteria: it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism explaining aging-related metabolic and vascular decline at the organismal level; it integrates biochemical, physiological, and biophysical mechanisms; it addresses systemic aging phenomena (metabolic syndrome and atherosclerosis) rather than narrow organ-specific or disease-specific phenomena; and it provides mechanistic explanations rather than mere correlations.

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial Dysfunction as a Central Cause
key_concepts.description: Mitochondrial dysfunction induced by environmental toxins such as endocrine-disrupting chemicals (EDCs) leads to decreased tissue energy production and metabolism, which underlies metabolic syndrome and atherosclerosis. This dysfunction reduces ATP and heat production, causing compensatory physiological changes.

key_concepts.concept: Adaptive Vascular Remodeling in Response to Decreased Energy Demand
key_concepts.description: Atherosclerosis is proposed as an ill-adaptive remodeling or narrowing of nutrient-supplying arteries in response to decreased tissue energy demand caused by mitochondrial dysfunction. This remodeling is not primarily due to arterial injury or cholesterol accumulation but reflects a systemic bioenergetic adaptation.

key_concepts.concept: Integration of Biophysical Laws and Fractal Physiology
key_concepts.description: The theory incorporates biophysical principles such as metabolic scaling law (Kleiber's law), Murray's law of vascular branching, and fractal geometry of the vascular system to explain how mitochondrial dysfunction affects vascular structure and function at multiple scales, linking microcirculation units to systemic aging phenomena.

key_concepts.concept: Role of Endocrine-Disrupting Chemicals (EDCs)
key_concepts.description: Exposure to persistent organic pollutants (POPs), a major group of EDCs, causes mitochondrial damage, oxidative stress, and inflammation, which initiate and propagate metabolic syndrome and atherosclerosis. EDCs act as injurious agents triggering mitochondrial dysfunction and vascular pathology.

key_concepts.concept: Link Between Mitochondrial Dysfunction, Endothelial Dysfunction, and Vascular Inflammation
key_concepts.description: Mitochondrial dysfunction in endothelial cells leads to disturbed nitric oxide (NO) bioavailability, increased reactive oxygen species (ROS), and inflammatory signaling, which contribute to endothelial dysfunction and vascular inflammation, key features of atherosclerosis.

key_concepts.concept: Microvascular Rarefaction and Tissue Microcirculation Unit Dysfunction
key_concepts.description: The basic physiological unit comprising tissue and its microcirculation is impaired due to mitochondrial dysfunction, leading to rarefaction (loss) of small vessels, reduced capillary recruitment, and impaired tissue perfusion, which are early and systemic features of metabolic and vascular aging.

key_concepts.concept: Thrifty Phenotype and Developmental Origins
key_concepts.description: Fetal malnutrition leads to decreased mitochondrial biogenesis and microvascular development, predisposing individuals to metabolic syndrome and atherosclerosis later in life, linking developmental programming to systemic aging and vascular disease.

title: Aging as a multi-step process characterized by a lowering of entropy production leading the cell to a sequence of defined stages.

theories.name: Thermodynamic theory of aging based on entropy production and error accumulation
theories.evidence: The paper reviews thermodynamic principles, cites experimental data on entropy production, free radical damage, antioxidant enzyme activity, cell division rates in tumor vs normal cells, and studies on stress effects on cells. It also references prior aging theories and integrates them into the thermodynamic framework.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory explains aging as a fundamental biological process at the cellular and organismal level, proposing causal mechanisms involving entropy production and error accumulation. It generalizes across cell types and links genetic and environmental factors, thus meeting all core criteria for an aging theory.

key_concepts.concept: Entropy production optimization in cells
key_concepts.description: Cells operate as open systems far from equilibrium and maintain steady states by optimizing free energy production through minimizing entropy production. Aging involves transitions between discrete steady states characterized by progressively lower entropy production.

key_concepts.concept: Increase of internal entropy and error accumulation
key_concepts.description: As cells age, internal errors (molecular alterations, structural disorganization) accumulate, increasing the internal entropy of the system. This accumulation destabilizes steady states and forces cells to transition to new states with lower entropy production, eventually leading to cell death when a critical threshold is reached.

key_concepts.concept: Integration of programmed and stochastic aging theories
key_concepts.description: This thermodynamic framework reconciles programmed aging theories (genetic control, differentiation programs) and stochastic theories (random molecular damage, free radicals) by viewing aging as a sequence of state transitions driven by both genetic constitution and environmental/energetic fluctuations.

key_concepts.concept: Role of mitosis in error dilution
key_concepts.description: Cell division dilutes accumulated errors by distributing them between daughter cells, thus delaying the transition to lower entropy production states. Rapidly dividing cells, such as tumor cells, maintain higher entropy production and resist aging-related decline by continuous error dilution.

key_concepts.concept: Impact of stresses on entropy production and aging
key_concepts.description: Different levels of stress (small, repeated/important, very severe) affect cellular entropy production and error levels differently. Small stresses cause temporary increases in entropy production and repair; repeated or severe stresses overwhelm defenses, causing irreversible errors, lowering entropy production, and accelerating aging or cell death.

key_concepts.concept: Aging as a multi-step process with discrete steady states
key_concepts.description: Cells progress through a series of discrete steady states with decreasing entropy production and increasing internal errors. Each state is stable until destabilized by accumulated errors or stresses, leading to a transition to a lower-energy state, reflecting a stepwise aging process.

title: Redox proteomics in aging rat brain: involvement of mitochondrial reduced glutathione status and mitochondrial protein oxidation in the aging process.

theories.name: Free Radical Theory of Aging
theories.evidence: The paper presents experimental data using redox proteomics to identify oxidatively modified mitochondrial proteins in aging rat brain regions (cortex, hippocampus), showing increased protein carbonylation and altered redox status; references to prior literature supporting ROS involvement in aging and neurodegeneration are also cited.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: the theory explains a fundamental, organism-level aging process (oxidative damage as a causal driver), proposes mechanisms (ROS-induced damage), and addresses broad aging phenomena beyond specific diseases, linking mitochondrial dysfunction and energy decline to systemic aging.

key_concepts.concept: Reactive Oxygen Species (ROS) as causal agents
key_concepts.description: ROS are highly reactive intermediates that cause oxidative damage to critical biological molecules such as proteins, DNA, and lipids, leading to cellular dysfunction and aging.

key_concepts.concept: Oxidative damage accumulation
key_concepts.description: With age, oxidative modifications accumulate in cellular macromolecules, especially proteins, which impairs their function and contributes to the decline in physiological functions.

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondria as both source and target
key_concepts.description: Mitochondria produce the majority of ROS and are particularly susceptible to oxidative damage, which impairs energy production and exacerbates aging-related decline.

key_concepts.concept: Protein carbonylation as a biomarker
key_concepts.description: Protein carbonyl groups increase with age, serving as markers of oxidative protein damage that reflect the extent of oxidative stress in aging tissues.

title: A Werner syndrome protein homolog affects C. elegans development, growth rate, life span and sensitivity to DNA damage by acting at a DNA damage checkpoint.

theories.name: DNA damage checkpoint theory of aging related to Werner syndrome protein
theories.evidence: RNA interference of wrn-1 in C. elegans caused reduced lifespan, premature aging signs (lipofuscin accumulation, tissue deterioration), developmental defects, and abnormal DNA damage checkpoint responses; phenotypes were exacerbated by gamma-irradiation; localization studies showed WRN-1 nuclear presence in dividing cells; comparisons to human WS cells and genetic data support the role of WRN in DNA repair and aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (DNA damage checkpoint failure leading to aging) applicable at organismal level, explains why aging occurs via genomic instability, and connects cellular defects to systemic aging phenotypes; not limited to a single tissue or disease but uses Werner syndrome as a model for fundamental aging processes.

key_concepts.concept: Role of WRN-1 in DNA damage response
key_concepts.description: WRN-1, a homolog of human Werner syndrome protein in C. elegans, acts as a checkpoint protein that detects and responds to DNA damage and replication blockage, thereby maintaining genomic stability.

key_concepts.concept: Genomic instability as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Loss or inhibition of WRN-1 leads to increased DNA damage, defective checkpoint responses, and accelerated cellular processes such as S phase, resulting in premature aging phenotypes including tissue deterioration and reduced lifespan.

key_concepts.concept: Werner syndrome as a model for accelerated aging
key_concepts.description: Mutations in the WRN gene cause Werner syndrome, characterized by premature aging and genomic instability, suggesting that defects in DNA repair and checkpoint mechanisms contribute causally to organismal aging.

title: Telomerase inhibition may contribute to accelerated mitochondrial aging induced by anti-retroviral HIV treatment.

theories.name: Telomerase Inhibition-Induced Mitochondrial Aging Theory
theories.mode: propose, discuss, review, critique, suggest experimental testing
theories.evidence: Citations of studies showing NRTI inhibition of telomerase activity in vitro and in vivo (cell lines, Tetrahymena, mice, humans), mitochondrial localization and protective roles of telomerase, differences in mitochondrial defects between NRTI-treated patients and pol γ mutation models, and correlation of telomerase inhibition potency with mitochondrial toxicity of NRTIs.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain a fundamental aging process (mitochondrial aging) at the organismal level by proposing a causal mechanism (telomerase inhibition leading to mitochondrial dysfunction and accelerated aging). It generalizes beyond a single organ or disease by linking telomerase's extratelomeric mitochondrial role to systemic aging phenomena. It is not limited to a narrow phenomenon and proposes an underlying cause of aging-related mitochondrial decline.

key_concepts.concept: NRTI-mediated telomerase inhibition
key_concepts.description: Nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs), used in HIV treatment, inhibit not only viral reverse transcriptase but also human telomerase, including its mitochondrial form, due to structural similarity.

key_concepts.concept: Extratelomeric mitochondrial protective role of telomerase
key_concepts.description: Telomerase, particularly its catalytic subunit hTERT, localizes to mitochondria where it binds mtDNA, acts as a reverse transcriptase independent of its RNA template, and protects mitochondrial function by improving respiratory chain activity and reducing oxidative stress.

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial dysfunction and accelerated aging via telomerase inhibition
key_concepts.description: Inhibition of mitochondrial telomerase by NRTIs impairs its protective functions, leading to accumulation and clonal expansion of mtDNA mutations, mitochondrial dysfunction, and premature mitochondrial aging observed in long-term treated HIV patients.

key_concepts.concept: Distinction from mtDNA polymerase γ inhibition
key_concepts.description: While NRTIs also inhibit mtDNA polymerase γ causing mitochondrial toxicity, telomerase inhibition provides an alternative or additional mechanism explaining mitochondrial defects that do not correlate well with polymerase γ inhibition or mtDNA depletion.

key_concepts.concept: Potential systemic impact despite low somatic telomerase activity
key_concepts.description: Although telomerase activity is low in most somatic cells, low-level hTERT expression and mitochondrial localization in various normal cells, including stem and progenitor cells, may allow mitochondrial telomerase inhibition to have systemic aging effects.

title: Impact of the Hayflick Limit on T cell responses to infection: lessons from aging and HIV disease.

theories.name: Replicative Senescence Theory of Aging
theories.evidence: The paper presents multiple lines of evidence including parallels between senescent T cells in vitro and CD8+CD28- T cells in elderly and HIV-infected individuals, telomere length measurements, functional assays showing loss of proliferation and cytotoxicity, apoptosis resistance studies, and correlations with clinical outcomes such as poor vaccine response and increased cancer incidence.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory explains a fundamental biological aging process (replicative senescence) with generalizability beyond a single organ or disease, proposes causal mechanisms (telomere shortening, loss of CD28, apoptosis resistance), and addresses systemic aging effects, thus meeting all core criteria for an aging theory.

key_concepts.concept: Hayflick Limit
key_concepts.description: Normal somatic cells have a finite replicative capacity, after which they enter irreversible cell cycle arrest, known as replicative senescence. This limit is a fundamental feature of normal somatic cells and is linked to telomere shortening.

key_concepts.concept: Telomere Shortening
key_concepts.description: Telomeres shorten with each cell division, and their length predicts the replicative potential of cells. Shortened telomeres trigger senescence, limiting cell proliferation and contributing to aging.

key_concepts.concept: Loss of CD28 Expression in T Cells
key_concepts.description: As CD8 T cells undergo repeated antigen-driven proliferation, they lose expression of the co-stimulatory molecule CD28, which is essential for T cell activation and proliferation. CD28- T cells are senescent and accumulate with age and in chronic HIV infection.

key_concepts.concept: Resistance to Apoptosis
key_concepts.description: Senescent T cells exhibit resistance to apoptosis, allowing their persistence in vivo, which may contribute to immune dysfunction during aging and HIV disease.

key_concepts.concept: Altered Function and Pro-inflammatory Cytokine Production
key_concepts.description: Senescent T cells show altered cytokine profiles, including increased production of pro-inflammatory cytokines such as TNF-alpha and IL-6, which may have systemic effects contributing to aging-related pathology.

key_concepts.concept: Reduced Immune Function
key_concepts.description: Senescent CD8 T cells have diminished proliferative capacity and reduced cytotoxic function, impairing control over viral infections and cancer, which are more prevalent in aging and HIV disease.

title: Purple pitanga fruit (Eugenia uniflora L.) protects against oxidative stress and increase the lifespan in Caenorhabditis elegans via the DAF-16/FOXO pathway.

theories.name: Oxidative Stress and DAF-16/FOXO Pathway Modulation Theory of Aging
theories.evidence: Experimental data in Caenorhabditis elegans showed that purple pitanga fruit extract increased lifespan, improved survival under oxidative stress (H2O2, juglone), decreased ROS levels and protein carbonylation, and upregulated DAF-16 target genes SOD-3 and HSP-16.2. The protective effects were absent in daf-16 mutants, indicating dependence on this pathway.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism for aging involving oxidative damage and a conserved genetic regulatory pathway (DAF-16/FOXO) that modulates systemic aging. The theory addresses organism-level aging processes and is supported by mechanistic evidence.

key_concepts.concept: Oxidative stress as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that accumulation of oxidative damage caused by reactive oxygen species (ROS) contributes causally to the aging process by damaging cellular components, leading to functional decline.

key_concepts.concept: DAF-16/FOXO transcription factor as a central regulator of lifespan
key_concepts.description: DAF-16, a FOXO family transcription factor in C. elegans, modulates expression of genes involved in stress resistance, antioxidant defenses (e.g., SOD-3), and proteostasis (e.g., HSP-16.2), thereby influencing organismal lifespan and aging.

key_concepts.concept: Antioxidant compounds can modulate aging by activating DAF-16
key_concepts.description: Bioactive compounds such as anthocyanins in purple pitanga fruit extract reduce oxidative stress and promote nuclear localization and activation of DAF-16, leading to increased expression of protective genes and lifespan extension.

title: Age- and passage-dependent upregulation of fibroblast elastase-type endopeptidase activity. Role of advanced glycation endproducts, inhibition by fucose- and rhamnose-rich oligosaccharides.

theories.name: Advanced Glycation Endproducts (AGEs)-Mediated Elastase Upregulation Theory of Aging
theories.evidence: Experimental data from in vitro human skin fibroblast cultures showing passage-dependent increases in elastase activity; addition of AGEs to culture media upregulated elastase activity; inhibition of this effect by specific oligosaccharides; prior literature on age-dependent collagen crosslinking and elastase activity in human and mouse tissues; use of specific inhibitors and zymography implicating MMP-9.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: The theory attempts to explain a fundamental aging process (tissue aging via extracellular matrix degradation) with a causal mechanism (AGE accumulation leading to elastase upregulation via receptor-mediated signaling). It is generalizable to organism-level aging as it relates to vascular and skin tissue aging, not limited to a single disease or organ without broader implications.

key_concepts.concept: AGE accumulation with age
key_concepts.description: Advanced glycation endproducts accumulate progressively in tissues with chronological age, leading to biochemical modifications such as collagen crosslinking that alter tissue properties.

key_concepts.concept: AGEs upregulate elastase-type endopeptidase activity
key_concepts.description: AGEs stimulate the increased production and activity of elastase-type endopeptidases, particularly matrix metalloproteinases like MMP-9, which degrade elastin and extracellular matrix components, contributing to tissue aging.

key_concepts.concept: AGE-receptor mediated signaling
key_concepts.description: The effect of AGEs on elastase activity is mediated through specific AGE receptors on fibroblasts, triggering signaling pathways that enhance elastase expression.

key_concepts.concept: Positive feedback via elastin degradation products
key_concepts.description: Elastin degradation products generated by elastase activity further stimulate elastase production, creating a self-amplifying loop that exacerbates tissue degradation.

key_concepts.concept: Inhibition by specific oligosaccharides
key_concepts.description: Fucose- and rhamnose-rich oligosaccharides (FROP-3 and RROP-3) can inhibit the AGE-induced upregulation of elastase activity, suggesting potential modulatory interventions targeting this pathway.

title: Mitochondrial DNA mutations and aging.

theories.name: Mitochondrial DNA Mutation Theory of Aging
theories.evidence: Citations of multiple studies showing mtDNA mutation accumulation in human and animal tissues; histochemical evidence of COX-deficient cells; mutator mouse model experiments demonstrating premature aging; molecular analyses of mtDNA deletions and point mutations; studies on oxidative damage markers; observations of mitochondrial dysfunction correlating with sarcopenia and neurodegeneration.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: generalizable as it explains a fundamental biological aging process across tissues and species; proposes causal mechanisms linking mtDNA mutations to aging phenotypes; addresses aging broadly beyond specific diseases; supported by experimental and correlative data.

key_concepts.concept: Accumulation of mtDNA mutations with age
key_concepts.description: Mitochondrial DNA mutations, including point mutations and large-scale deletions, accumulate in various tissues with age, leading to mitochondrial dysfunction.

key_concepts.concept: Threshold effect and clonal expansion
key_concepts.description: A critical ratio of mutated to wild-type mtDNA must be exceeded within individual cells to cause respiratory chain deficiency; mutated mtDNA can clonally expand within cells, especially in post-mitotic tissues.

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial dysfunction leads to cellular energy decline
key_concepts.description: Mutations impair oxidative phosphorylation (OXPHOS), reducing cellular energy production and potentially leading to cell dysfunction or death.

key_concepts.concept: Vicious cycle hypothesis
key_concepts.description: Mutated mtDNA causes defective OXPHOS, increasing reactive oxygen species (ROS) production, which further damages mtDNA, amplifying mitochondrial dysfunction.

key_concepts.concept: Evidence from mutator mouse model
key_concepts.description: Polymerase gamma proofreading-deficient mice accumulate high levels of mtDNA mutations and exhibit premature aging phenotypes, supporting a causal role of mtDNA mutations in aging.

key_concepts.concept: Role of mitochondrial quality control
key_concepts.description: Autophagy and mitophagy regulate mitochondrial turnover; impaired removal of mutated mitochondria may contribute to accumulation of dysfunctional mitochondria with age.

title: Age-related changes of accuracy and efficiency of protein synthesis machinery in rat.

theories.name: General Error Theory of Aging
theories.evidence: Experimental data from rat liver cell-free protein synthesis systems showed increased incorporation errors ([3H]leucine/[14C]phenylalanine ratio) with age. Charging kinetics and binding assays indicated that aged tRNAs and ribosomes contribute to decreased accuracy. The study cites prior theoretical and experimental works supporting the general error theory.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It attempts to explain WHY aging occurs at a fundamental organismal level by proposing a causal mechanism (accumulation of molecular errors affecting protein synthesis). It is generalizable beyond a single organ or disease, addressing a fundamental biological process of aging.

key_concepts.concept: Accumulation of stochastic errors
key_concepts.description: The theory proposes that aging results from a progressive accumulation of correlated and self-propagating stochastic errors, including somatic mutations, errors in translation, transcription, and DNA repair, leading to an exponential increase of macromolecular errors.

key_concepts.concept: Decline in accuracy and efficiency of protein synthesis machinery
key_concepts.description: Aging is characterized by decreased accuracy and efficiency in protein synthesis, evidenced by increased errors in amino acid incorporation during translation, which may contribute to the production and accumulation of partially active or inactive enzymes.

key_concepts.concept: Role of gene redundancy and meiotic rectification
key_concepts.description: Genes involved in protein synthesis (tRNA, rRNA, 5S RNA) exist in multiple copies; somatic mutations in these reiterated genes progressively impair protein synthesis accuracy and efficiency. Meiotic rectification events in germ cells may restore gene homogeneity and accuracy at the start of individual life.

title: GHK and DNA: resetting the human genome to health.

theories.name: Gene Expression Resetting Theory of Aging by GHK
theories.evidence: The paper presents gene expression profiling data showing GHK upregulates hundreds of genes involved in repair, antioxidant defense, DNA repair, and proteasome function while downregulating harmful genes. It cites in vivo animal studies demonstrating systemic wound healing and tissue regeneration effects of GHK, as well as cell culture studies showing reactivation of apoptosis in cancer cells and repair in COPD fibroblasts. The paper also references prior literature on insulin/IGF-1 signaling and aging, and experimental data on antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effects of GHK.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory meets all criteria: it attempts to explain aging as a fundamental process via gene expression changes; it proposes causal mechanisms (gene activity modulation) underlying aging; it addresses aging broadly at the organismal level through systemic gene resetting; and it is supported by mechanistic data and in vivo evidence.

key_concepts.concept: Age-related gene expression changes
key_concepts.description: Aging is characterized by increased activity of inflammatory, cancer-promoting, and tissue-destructive genes, alongside decreased activity of regenerative and reparative genes, which collectively drive the aging process.

key_concepts.concept: GHK as a gene expression modulator
key_concepts.description: The tripeptide GHK declines with age and can reset gene expression in aged or diseased cells to a more youthful, healthy state by activating reparative, antioxidant, DNA repair, and proteasome genes while suppressing harmful genes such as those promoting inflammation, cancer, and insulin/IGF-1 signaling.

key_concepts.concept: Multi-pathway systemic rejuvenation
key_concepts.description: GHK influences multiple aging-related pathways simultaneously, including enhancing the ubiquitin-proteasome system for protein quality control, stimulating DNA repair mechanisms, increasing antioxidant defenses, suppressing insulin/IGF-1 signaling linked to longevity, and promoting tissue repair via TGF-beta superfamily signaling.

key_concepts.concept: Therapeutic potential of gene resetting
key_concepts.description: By resetting gene expression profiles, GHK may delay or reverse aging-related decline and diseases such as cancer, COPD, and tissue degeneration, suggesting a systemic, fundamental approach to aging intervention rather than targeting isolated pathways.

title: Preferential degradation of oxidized proteins by the 20S proteasome may be inhibited in aging and in inflammatory neuromuscular diseases.

theories.name: Free Radical Theory of Aging with Proteasome Dysfunction Extension
theories.evidence: The paper cites multiple experimental studies demonstrating increased protein oxidation with age, selective degradation of oxidized proteins by the 20S proteasome in vitro and in cells, proteasome inhibition by aggregated proteins, and decline in proteasome activity during aging and disease. It also references genetic and biochemical data from model organisms linking oxidative stress to lifespan regulation.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: The theory explains WHY aging occurs at a fundamental level via oxidative damage and proteasome dysfunction; it proposes causal mechanisms involving free radicals and proteasome-mediated protein quality control; it is generalizable to organismal aging and age-related diseases; and it addresses systemic aging processes rather than narrow phenomena.

key_concepts.concept: Free Radical-Induced Oxidative Damage
key_concepts.description: Free radicals generated primarily by mitochondrial aerobic respiration and chronic inflammation cause cumulative oxidative damage to cellular macromolecules, including proteins, DNA, and lipids. This damage accumulates over time and contributes to biological aging and age-related diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Selective Degradation of Mildly Oxidized Proteins by the 20S Proteasome
key_concepts.description: Moderately oxidized proteins undergo partial unfolding that exposes hydrophobic residues, which are recognized and selectively degraded by the 20S proteasome without requiring ubiquitin tagging or ATP. This process prevents accumulation of damaged proteins and maintains cellular homeostasis.

key_concepts.concept: Proteasome Inhibition by Severely Oxidized and Crosslinked Protein Aggregates
key_concepts.description: Heavily oxidized, aggregated, and crosslinked proteins are poor substrates for the proteasome and can inhibit its activity. During aging and in neuromuscular degenerative diseases, accumulation of such protein aggregates progressively impairs proteasome function.

key_concepts.concept: Age-Related Decline in Proteasome Activity and Increased Oxidative Stress
key_concepts.description: Aging involves both increased generation of reactive oxygen species and a decline in proteasome activity, leading to accumulation of oxidized protein aggregates. This accumulation contributes to cellular dysfunction, senescence, and the pathogenesis of age-related disorders.

key_concepts.concept: Ubiquitinylation as a Consequence of Protein Aggregation
key_concepts.description: Heavily oxidized and aggregated proteins undergo progressive ubiquitinylation, not as a targeting mechanism for degradation, but as a secondary effect due to their prolonged cellular persistence, which may further promote aggregation and cellular damage.

title: Priming, Triggering, Adaptation and Senescence (PTAS): A Hypothesis for a Common Damage Mechanism of Steatohepatitis.

theories.name: Priming, Triggering, Adaptation and Senescence (PTAS) Hypothesis
theories.evidence: Supported by clinical observations in human ASH/NASH patients and multiple animal models (e.g., DDC mouse model, ferrochelatase-deficient mice), molecular data on PPAR downregulation, mitochondrial dysfunction, oxidative stress, hypoxic signaling, and senescence markers. Therapeutic effects of PPAR agonists and genetic models corroborate the priming and triggering phases.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It proposes a generalizable, causal, mechanistic explanation for the development and progression of steatohepatitis as a model of aging-related liver damage. It addresses systemic cellular aging processes (senescence), metabolic adaptation, and damage accumulation, linking molecular mechanisms to organism-level pathology.

key_concepts.concept: Priming
key_concepts.description: An initial phase where stress defense mechanisms in hepatocytes are lowered without causing significant damage, sensitizing cells to subsequent insults. This involves downregulation of PPAR and related stress response genes, impairing resilience to oxidative and metabolic stress.

key_concepts.concept: Triggering
key_concepts.description: An acute damaging event that induces hepatocellular injury, often mitochondrial dysfunction such as inhibition of succinate dehydrogenase (complex II), leading to oxidative stress, ATP depletion, and metabolic disruption. Triggering exacerbates damage in primed cells.

key_concepts.concept: Adaptation
key_concepts.description: A chronic phase where hepatocytes undergo metabolic and cellular adaptations to mitigate acute damage and maintain basal liver function at a lower level. This includes activation of hypoxic signaling (HIF-1/2), autophagy/mitophagy, inflammation, and wound healing responses, often associated with cellular senescence.

key_concepts.concept: Senescence and Sequelae
key_concepts.description: Cellular senescence acts as a tumor suppressive mechanism preventing neoplastic transformation but promotes fibrosis, inflammation, and progressive liver dysfunction. Escape from senescence can lead to hepatocellular carcinoma, representing late-stage disease progression.

key_concepts.concept: Common Damage Mechanism (CDM)
key_concepts.description: Despite diverse etiologies, different insults converge on a shared damage pathway involving the four PTAS phases, explaining the common phenotype of steatohepatitis and its progression to cirrhosis and cancer.

title: Ablation of insulin-producing cells prevents obesity but not premature mortality caused by a high-sugar diet in Drosophila.

theories.name: Insulin/IGF Signalling (IIS) Reduction Theory of Aging
theories.evidence: Experimental genetic ablation of mNSCs in Drosophila showed lifespan extension and improved climbing ability on both normal and high-sugar diets; however, lifespan shortening by excess sugar was not rescued. TAG measurements demonstrated prevention of sugar-induced obesity by mNSC ablation independent of dfoxo. Statistical analyses including Cox Proportional Hazards and mixed effects models supported these findings.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory explains HOW biological aging occurs via IIS signalling pathways at an organismal level, proposing causal mechanisms for lifespan modulation and healthspan. It is generalizable across organisms, addresses systemic aging, and is supported by mechanistic genetic interventions.

key_concepts.concept: IIS pathway as a modulator of lifespan
key_concepts.description: The insulin/IGF signalling pathway is an evolutionarily conserved network that modulates lifespan across multiple organisms. Reduction in IIS signalling, such as by genetic ablation of insulin-producing cells, extends lifespan and delays age-related decline.

key_concepts.concept: Genetic ablation of median neurosecretory cells (mNSCs)
key_concepts.description: Ablation of mNSCs, which produce insulin-like peptides in Drosophila, reduces IIS signalling and robustly extends lifespan, counteracting detrimental effects of excess dietary protein.

key_concepts.concept: IIS reduction improves neuromuscular health
key_concepts.description: Reduction in IIS delays age-related decline in neuromuscular function, as measured by climbing ability, indicating systemic anti-aging effects beyond lifespan extension.

key_concepts.concept: IIS reduction prevents obesity independently of canonical dfoxo pathway
key_concepts.description: While IIS reduction extends lifespan via the dfoxo transcription factor, the prevention of sugar-induced obesity by IIS reduction occurs independently of dfoxo, suggesting alternative IIS downstream pathways regulate metabolism.

key_concepts.concept: Limitations of IIS reduction under high-sugar diet
key_concepts.description: Although IIS reduction extends lifespan and improves health irrespective of dietary sugar, it cannot rescue the lifespan-shortening effects of excess sugar, indicating that sugar’s detrimental effects are mediated by IIS-independent mechanisms.

title: The PICLS high-throughput screening method for agents extending cellular longevity identifies 2,5-anhydro-D-mannitol as novel anti-aging compound.

theories.name: Calorie Restriction Theory of Aging
theories.evidence: Experimental data showing extended yeast CLS under reduced glucose conditions validated by propidium iodide fluorescence and traditional outgrowth assays; citations of prior work on calorie restriction in multiple organisms.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal mechanism for aging involving nutrient sensing and metabolic regulation applicable beyond yeast to broader organisms.

key_concepts.concept: Calorie restriction extends lifespan
key_concepts.description: Reducing glucose concentration in the growth medium extends the chronological lifespan (CLS) of yeast, modeling how reduced caloric intake delays aging processes in post-mitotic cells.

key_concepts.concept: Metabolic and signaling modulation
key_concepts.description: Calorie restriction influences nutrient-sensing pathways such as TORC1 and AMPK, which regulate cellular growth, metabolism, and aging.

theories.name: Glycolytic Flux Modulation Theory of Aging
theories.evidence: Biochemical knowledge of 2,5-AM metabolism and its inhibitory effect on aldolase; experimental identification of 2,5-AM as a novel anti-aging compound extending yeast CLS; discussion of metabolic pathways linking glycolysis to aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a mechanistic, generalizable explanation of aging via metabolic pathway modulation affecting systemic aging processes.

key_concepts.concept: Glycolysis intermediates regulate aging
key_concepts.description: Metabolites such as DHAP act as glucose signals activating TORC1, linking glycolytic flux to aging regulation.

key_concepts.concept: 2,5-AM inhibits aldolase
key_concepts.description: 2,5-AM is phosphorylated to 2,5-AMBP, which inhibits aldolase, reducing conversion of fructose-1,6-bisphosphate to downstream glycolytic intermediates, potentially altering energy metabolism and aging.

key_concepts.concept: Metabolic signaling impacts lifespan
key_concepts.description: Changes in glycolytic flux affect ATP production and signaling pathways (e.g., AMPK activation), influencing cellular aging.

theories.name: TORC1/AMPK Nutrient-Sensing Aging Theory
theories.evidence: Discussion of known literature on TORC1 and AMPK roles in aging; speculation on 2,5-anhydro-D-mannitol (2,5-AM) potentially modulating these pathways based on its metabolic effects.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it explains causal mechanisms of aging at organismal level via conserved nutrient-sensing pathways.

key_concepts.concept: TORC1 promotes growth and aging
key_concepts.description: The TORC1 complex senses nutrient availability and promotes cell growth and proliferation, with its inhibition linked to lifespan extension.

key_concepts.concept: AMPK as energy sensor
key_concepts.description: AMPK is activated under low energy conditions, inhibits TORC1, and promotes cellular homeostasis and longevity.

key_concepts.concept: Antagonistic interaction
key_concepts.description: TORC1 and AMPK have opposing roles that balance growth and maintenance, influencing aging rates.

title: Role of autophagy in aging: The good, the bad, and the ugly.

theories.name: Autophagy theory of aging
theories.evidence: Citations of genetic knockout studies showing accelerated aging phenotypes upon autophagy gene loss; lifespan extension by autophagy gene overexpression in yeast, worms, flies, and mice; observations of autophagy decline in aged tissues; molecular studies linking autophagy regulation to nutrient sensing pathways; data on autophagy’s role in senescence and tumorigenesis.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: The theory is generalizable as it explains aging as a fundamental organismal process via cellular maintenance mechanisms; it provides causal explanations by linking autophagy activity to aging phenotypes and lifespan; it addresses aging broadly beyond specific organs or diseases by focusing on cellular homeostasis and systemic aging.

key_concepts.concept: Autophagy as a homeostatic cellular process
key_concepts.description: Autophagy is a conserved catabolic mechanism that removes damaged molecules and organelles, maintaining cellular homeostasis and metabolic demands. It prevents accumulation of cellular damage that contributes to aging.

key_concepts.concept: Decline of autophagy with age
key_concepts.description: Aging is associated with a decline in autophagy gene expression and autophagic activity, leading to loss of cellular homeostasis, accumulation of damaged proteins and organelles, and increased cellular dysfunction.

key_concepts.concept: Dual role of autophagy in aging and senescence
key_concepts.description: Autophagy can both prevent senescence by maintaining cellular health and paradoxically support the maintenance of senescent cells and their secretory phenotype (SASP), indicating a complex, context-dependent role in aging.

key_concepts.concept: Autophagy modulation affects lifespan
key_concepts.description: Genetic or pharmacological enhancement of autophagy extends lifespan in model organisms, while impairment accelerates aging phenotypes, suggesting autophagy is causally linked to aging processes.

key_concepts.concept: Mitophagy and selective autophagy in aging
key_concepts.description: Selective forms of autophagy, such as mitophagy, are critical for removing damaged mitochondria; decline in mitophagy rather than general autophagy may contribute to premature aging and progeroid syndromes.

key_concepts.concept: Regulation of autophagy by nutrient and energy sensors
key_concepts.description: Autophagy is regulated by key signaling pathways including mTOR inhibition and AMPK activation, which respond to nutrient availability and cellular energy status, linking metabolic state to aging.

title: A qualitative study of nursing staff members' interpretations of signs of gerotranscendence.

theories.name: Gerotranscendence Theory
theories.evidence: The paper uses qualitative interviews with nursing staff to explore recognition and interpretation of signs of gerotranscendence in older adults. It references Tornstam's original works and related studies, and analyzes staff interpretations of behaviors aligned with the theory's signs.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable, causal explanation of aging as a developmental process affecting the whole person, including psychosocial dimensions. It explains why and how aging occurs at a broad organism-level scale, not limited to disease or organ-specific phenomena.

key_concepts.concept: Natural developmental process
key_concepts.description: Gerotranscendence is described as a natural developmental process of aging, involving a shift in an older person's meta-perspective and a new outlook on reality, rather than a pathological decline.

key_concepts.concept: Three levels of ontological change
key_concepts.description: The theory identifies changes on three levels: the cosmic level (e.g., altered perception of time and space, decreased fear of death, acceptance of life's mysteries), the self level (e.g., self-confrontation, decreased self-centeredness, body transcendence, self-transcendence), and social and personal relations (e.g., changed meaning of relationships, role-play awareness, emancipated innocence, everyday wisdom).

key_concepts.concept: Shift from egoism to altruism and new life perspective
key_concepts.description: A key mechanism is the shift from self-centeredness and egoism towards altruism and a broader, more transcendent understanding of life, death, and social roles.

key_concepts.concept: Variability in individual progression
key_concepts.description: Not all individuals reach a high degree of gerotranscendence; it is a process that can be optimized and varies among older adults.

title: Profiles of random change during aging contain hidden information about longevity and the aging process.

theories.name: Budding Profile Correlation Theory of Yeast Aging
theories.evidence: The paper presents experimental data from three independent yeast cell cohorts (Experiments I-III) with detailed tracking of budding patterns and lifespans. A discriminant function model (eqn 2) was derived and validated on independent samples, showing high accuracy in predicting longevity based on budding profiles. Statistical analyses demonstrate significant correlations and low misclassification rates. The association of random budding frequency with longer lifespan was confirmed by grouping cells by this metric.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory meets all core criteria: it attempts to explain WHY aging occurs at the organismal level (yeast replicative lifespan) by proposing a causal mechanism involving changes in cellular spatial organization (budding patterns). It generalizes beyond a narrow phenomenon by linking morphological stochasticity to longevity. It provides a causal explanation by hypothesizing that random budding influences lifespan, not merely describing correlations. The scope addresses aging broadly in yeast as a model organism, with implications for higher organisms suggested. Thus, it qualifies as a valid biological aging theory.

key_concepts.concept: Budding profiles as individual aging signatures
key_concepts.description: Each yeast cell exhibits a unique pattern of axial and random budding events during its replicative lifespan, which can be mathematically characterized as a 'budding profile'. These profiles reflect cellular spatial organization and polarity changes that occur stochastically over time.

key_concepts.concept: Correlation between budding profiles and longevity
key_concepts.description: Quantitative analysis shows that specific features of the budding profile, especially the frequency of random budding events, are strongly correlated with the lifespan of individual yeast cells. Cells with higher frequencies of random budding tend to live longer.

key_concepts.concept: Random budding as a potential causal factor in aging
key_concepts.description: Contrary to expectations that random budding increases with age as a sign of decline, the study proposes that increased random budding may actively contribute to extended longevity, suggesting a causal role of spatial organization changes in aging.

key_concepts.concept: Top-down mathematical modeling approach
key_concepts.description: A discriminant function combining multiple budding profile variables reduces complex spatial and temporal budding data into a single predictive metric (B value) that accurately classifies cells as short- or long-lived, enabling hypothesis generation about causal aging mechanisms.

title: Mitochondrial DNA deletions in human cardiac tissue show a gross mosaic distribution.

theories.name: Mitochondrial DNA Deletion Accumulation Theory of Aging
theories.evidence: Quantitative and qualitative PCR analyses of mtDNA deletions (especially the common 4977 bp deletion) in multiple adjacent slices of human cardiac tissue from 10 subjects aged 43-74 showed variable abundance and distinct deletion patterns, supporting the mosaic and cumulative nature of mtDNA deletions during aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a generalizable causal mechanism (mtDNA deletion accumulation) underlying aging, supported by data from human tissue; addresses aging broadly as a fundamental process involving mitochondrial genome integrity; not limited to a specific disease or organ alone but connected to systemic aging mechanisms.

key_concepts.concept: Random accumulation of mtDNA deletions
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that mitochondrial DNA deletions occur randomly throughout an individual's lifetime, accumulating progressively in postmitotic tissues such as cardiac muscle.

key_concepts.concept: Gross mosaic distribution of mtDNA deletions
key_concepts.description: Within a given tissue, mtDNA deletions are not evenly distributed but show a mosaic pattern, with adjacent tissue slices exhibiting highly variable deletion patterns and abundances.

key_concepts.concept: Propagation and segregation of mtDNA mutations
key_concepts.description: New deletions are superimposed on previously accumulated mutations, which propagate and segregate within cells over time, contributing to the heterogeneity of mtDNA deletions in tissues.

key_concepts.concept: Contribution to aging via mitochondrial dysfunction
key_concepts.description: Accumulation of mtDNA deletions impairs mitochondrial function, which is hypothesized to contribute causally to the aging process at the organismal level.

title: The Rarity of Survival to Old Age Does Not Drive the Evolution of Senescence.

theories.name: Disposable soma theory of aging
theories.evidence: Theoretical optimization models and mathematical proofs showing that age-independent mortality does not alter the optimal trade-off between reproduction and maintenance; references to classical works by Kirkwood and colleagues.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it is a general, causal evolutionary theory explaining why aging occurs via resource allocation trade-offs at the organism level.

key_concepts.concept: Resource allocation trade-off between somatic maintenance and reproduction
key_concepts.description: Organisms allocate limited resources either to maintaining their soma (body) to slow aging or to reproduction. Investment in reproduction at the cost of maintenance leads to senescence as an evolutionarily optimal strategy.

key_concepts.concept: Extrinsic mortality shapes optimal allocation
key_concepts.description: Traditional view holds that higher extrinsic mortality reduces the benefit of investing in somatic maintenance, favoring faster senescence. However, the paper challenges this by showing age-independent mortality does not affect optimal strategies.

theories.name: Evolutionary theory of senescence based on declining selection gradients
theories.evidence: Mathematical derivations and models based on Euler-Lotka equations and Hamilton's selection gradients; citations of prior theoretical work (Abrams 1993; Caswell 2007; Caswell and Shyu 2016) and empirical studies showing lack of support for classical predictions; hypothetical scenarios including zero mortality and age-independent mortality terms.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: It is a generalizable evolutionary theory explaining why senescence occurs at the organismal level, provides causal mechanisms (declining selection gradients shaped by stable age distribution and reproduction), and addresses aging broadly rather than focusing on specific organs or diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Declining selection gradients with age
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that senescence evolves because the strength of natural selection acting on traits declines with age. This decline means that deleterious effects manifesting late in life are less strongly selected against, allowing senescence to evolve.

key_concepts.concept: Role of stable age distribution rather than survivorship alone
key_concepts.description: Contrary to traditional views, the decline in selection gradients is driven not directly by declining survivorship with age but by the shape of the stable age distribution, which is influenced by reproduction and population growth. Even with zero mortality, selection gradients decline due to the abundance of younger individuals.

key_concepts.concept: Age-independent mortality does not affect selection gradients
key_concepts.description: Adding age-independent extrinsic mortality changes survivorship but does not alter the selection gradients or optimal life history strategies, challenging the widespread assumption that higher extrinsic mortality accelerates senescence.

key_concepts.concept: Reproductive value and population dynamics shape selection pressures
key_concepts.description: Selection gradients depend on the reproductive value of individuals at different ages weighted by their proportional abundance in the population, emphasizing the importance of births and population growth in shaping evolutionary pressures on aging.

title: Nutritional ecology and the evolution of aging.

theories.name: Nutritional Ecology Framework for the Evolution of Aging
theories.evidence: The paper reviews empirical studies using the Geometric Framework in insects and mice, showing how nutrient balance affects lifespan and reproduction. It discusses experimental designs manipulating nutrient ratios and quantities, and cites multiple studies demonstrating lifespan extension on low-protein high-carbohydrate diets and differential nutrient optima for sexes.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The framework attempts to explain how aging occurs through evolved nutritional regulatory mechanisms interacting with ecological nutrient availability, providing a causal explanation linking diet composition to lifespan and reproduction at the organismal level. It is generalizable across taxa and integrates evolutionary and mechanistic perspectives, thus meeting all core criteria for an aging theory.

key_concepts.concept: Geometric Framework for Nutrition
key_concepts.description: A multidimensional state-space modeling approach that represents the interaction between animals and their nutritional environment by distinguishing calories, individual nutrients, and nutrient balance. It models nutrient intake targets and regulatory responses to dietary variation.

key_concepts.concept: Homeostatic Regulatory Responses
key_concepts.description: Animals actively regulate their nutrient intake to achieve evolved intake targets through mechanisms such as appetite control. When constrained by ecological factors, animals employ 'rules of compromise' to balance nutrient surpluses and deficits, reflecting evolved priorities.

key_concepts.concept: Qualitative and Quantitative Dietary Restriction
key_concepts.description: Dietary restriction is conceptualized as either quantitative (overall food amount reduction) or qualitative (nutrient balance or concentration changes). These distinctions are critical for understanding how diet influences lifespan and reproduction.

key_concepts.concept: Trade-offs Between Longevity and Reproduction Mediated by Nutrient Balance
key_concepts.description: Different macronutrient balances optimize lifespan and reproductive output differently, with low-protein high-carbohydrate diets favoring longevity and higher protein diets favoring reproduction, indicating evolved nutritional priorities and sexual dimorphism in nutrient optimization.

key_concepts.concept: Integration of Evolutionary and Mechanistic Aging Theories via Ecology
key_concepts.description: Ecology, particularly nutritional ecology, provides a framework to integrate evolutionary theories (e.g., natural selection shaping nutrient regulation) with mechanistic aging processes by focusing on the environmental context in which aging mechanisms evolved.

title: The aging myocardium: roles of mitochondrial damage and lysosomal degradation.

theories.name: Mitochondrial-Lysosomal Aging Theory of Postmitotic Cell Senescence
theories.evidence: The paper presents extensive literature citations on mitochondrial structural changes, mtDNA mutations, lysosomal lipofuscin accumulation, and impaired autophagy in aging cardiac myocytes. It includes microscopy data showing mitochondrial membrane potential decline and lipofuscin increase in cultured cardiac cells. Theoretical and experimental support for oxidative stress as a driver of damage and lipofuscin formation is discussed, along with references to protease activity and autophagy mechanisms.
theories.criteria_reasoning: This theory meets all criteria: it provides a generalizable explanation for aging in long-lived postmitotic cells, proposes causal mechanisms involving mitochondrial damage, impaired autophagy, and lysosomal dysfunction, and addresses systemic aging processes rather than narrow phenomena.

key_concepts.concept: Accumulation of damaged mitochondria
key_concepts.description: Mitochondria in long-lived postmitotic cells accumulate structural damage, including enlargement, loss of cristae, and mtDNA mutations, leading to decreased ATP production and increased reactive oxygen species (ROS) generation.

key_concepts.concept: Imperfect autophagic turnover
key_concepts.description: The autophagic removal of damaged mitochondria is impaired due to mitochondrial enlargement, decreased membrane damage signaling, and suppression of autophagy caused by lysosomal lipofuscin accumulation.

key_concepts.concept: Lipofuscin accumulation in lysosomes
key_concepts.description: Lipofuscin, an undegradable autofluorescent polymeric pigment formed from oxidatively damaged macromolecules, accumulates within lysosomes, reducing their capacity to degrade cellular waste and limiting availability of lysosomal hydrolases for functional autophagy.

key_concepts.concept: Interrelated mitochondrial and lysosomal damage
key_concepts.description: Damaged mitochondria produce more ROS, which promotes further mitochondrial injury and lipofuscin formation, creating a vicious cycle that progressively impairs cellular turnover and leads to functional failure and death of long-lived postmitotic cells such as cardiac myocytes.

key_concepts.concept: Role of proteases and mtDNA repair insufficiency
key_concepts.description: Decreased efficiency of mitochondrial proteases (Lon and AAA) and insufficient mtDNA repair contribute to accumulation of defective mitochondria.

title: Testing the oxidative stress hypothesis of aging in primate fibroblasts: is there a correlation between species longevity and cellular ROS production?

theories.name: Oxidative Stress Theory of Aging
theories.evidence: Experimental data from cultured fibroblasts of 13 primate species measuring mitochondrial ROS production, cellular ROS levels, and apoptosis induced by oxidative and other stressors; statistical analyses including regression, residuals correcting for body mass, and phylogenetically independent contrasts; citations of prior studies supporting or contextualizing findings.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The oxidative stress theory is a generalizable biological aging theory proposing a causal mechanism (ROS-induced damage) underlying aging across species; the paper tests key predictions of this theory in primates, addressing organism-level longevity and cellular mechanisms; it goes beyond narrow phenomena by linking cellular oxidative stress resistance to species lifespan.

key_concepts.concept: Mitochondrial Reactive Oxygen Species (ROS) Production
key_concepts.description: The theory posits that aging is driven by the accumulation of damage caused by reactive oxygen species produced primarily in mitochondria. Lower mitochondrial ROS production is hypothesized to correlate with increased species longevity.

key_concepts.concept: Cellular Resistance to Oxidative Stress
key_concepts.description: Longer-lived species exhibit greater cellular resistance to oxidative stress-induced apoptosis, suggesting that enhanced defense mechanisms against oxidative damage contribute to longevity.

key_concepts.concept: Body Mass and Phylogenetic Confounding
key_concepts.description: The observed inverse correlation between mitochondrial ROS production and longevity is confounded by body mass and phylogenetic relatedness, indicating that these factors influence mitochondrial ROS levels and longevity independently.

key_concepts.concept: Metabolic Stress and ROS Production
key_concepts.description: Under metabolic stress (e.g., high glucose), mitochondrial ROS production increases, but this increase is blunted in cells from longer-lived primates, linking metabolic stress resistance to longevity.

key_concepts.concept: Role of Antioxidant Systems and Repair Mechanisms
key_concepts.description: Differences in antioxidant enzyme activities (e.g., superoxide dismutase) and repair of oxidative damage may underlie interspecies differences in oxidative stress resistance and longevity.

title: Testing evolutionary explanations for the lifespan benefit of dietary restriction in fruit flies (Drosophila melanogaster).

theories.name: Nutrient Recycling Hypothesis (NRH)
theories.evidence: Experimental results showed that lifespan extension under DR persisted even with added stressors (infection and injury), contradicting NRH predictions; infected flies on low protein had poor survival but DR lifespan extension was not abolished.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as it proposes a causal evolutionary mechanism explaining aging-related lifespan changes; however, the paper's data do not support its predictions.

key_concepts.concept: Selective benefit through reproduction maintenance
key_concepts.description: The hypothesis suggests that the primary selective benefit of DR is maintaining immediate reproduction rather than survival.

key_concepts.concept: Upregulation of nutrient recycling pathways
key_concepts.description: DR inhibits nutrient-sensing pathways (e.g., TOR, IIS), leading to increased apoptosis and autophagy, which recycle nutrients to support reproduction.

key_concepts.concept: Lifespan extension as laboratory artifact
key_concepts.description: Lifespan extension under DR is proposed to be a side effect of benign laboratory conditions; under natural stressors like infection or injury, DR individuals would be frailer and lifespan extension would disappear.

theories.name: Resource Reallocation Hypothesis (RRH)
theories.evidence: Experimental data from Drosophila melanogaster showing lifespan extension and delayed aging under protein restriction across control, injury, and infection stress treatments; survival maximized at intermediate protein levels; reproduction decreased with protein restriction; aging measures (gut integrity, climbing ability) consistent with delayed aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: generalizable to organism-level aging, proposes causal mechanisms (resource allocation trade-off), addresses broad aging processes beyond specific organs or diseases.

key_concepts.concept: Adaptive resource investment shift
key_concepts.description: Under dietary restriction (DR), organisms adaptively shift resource allocation from reproduction to somatic maintenance and survival, delaying reproduction until conditions improve.

key_concepts.concept: Trade-off between reproduction and survival
key_concepts.description: The theory posits a fundamental trade-off where investing resources into survival reduces reproduction temporarily, optimizing fitness in fluctuating environments.

key_concepts.concept: Evolutionary basis in fluctuating environments
key_concepts.description: The response evolved because environments fluctuate between low and high food availability, favoring survival during scarcity to maximize lifetime reproductive success.

title: Pterostilbene Targets Hallmarks of Aging in the Gene Expression Landscape in Blood of Healthy Rats.

theories.name: Cellular Homeostasis Maintenance via Autophagy and Proteostasis Theory
theories.evidence: PTS treatment downregulated ribosomal components (Rn58s, Rps16) and genes inhibiting autophagy (Itsn1), while promoting autophagy-related pathways. Prior studies link autophagy and proteostasis to aging.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory explains mechanisms of aging at the cellular and organismal level, proposing causal pathways involving autophagy and proteostasis, consistent with accepted aging theories.

key_concepts.concept: Autophagy as a key anti-aging mechanism
key_concepts.description: Enhanced autophagy removes damaged organelles and proteins, maintaining cellular function and preventing age-related decline.

key_concepts.concept: Proteostasis and ribosomal biogenesis regulation
key_concepts.description: Reduced ribosomal biogenesis decreases energy expenditure and protein synthesis stress, contributing to longevity by maintaining proteostasis.

theories.name: Dietary Restriction Mimicry via Amino Acid Transport Modulation Theory
theories.evidence: PTS supplementation in rats decreased Slc7a5 expression. Literature supports that Slc7a5 knockdown hinders amino acid uptake, prevents mTOR activation, and promotes autophagy. Dietary restriction is a well-established longevity intervention.
theories.criteria_reasoning: This theory proposes a causal mechanism for aging modulation via nutrient sensing pathways at the organismal level and links to general aging processes, fulfilling aging theory criteria.

key_concepts.concept: Reduced amino acid uptake mimics dietary restriction
key_concepts.description: Downregulation of amino acid transporters such as Slc7a5 reduces essential amino acid uptake, triggering cellular pathways similar to dietary restriction that promote longevity.

key_concepts.concept: mTOR inhibition and autophagy activation
key_concepts.description: Reduced amino acid availability inhibits mTORC1 signaling, enhancing autophagy and cellular homeostasis, which are linked to lifespan extension.

theories.name: Epigenetic Regulation and Chromatin State Alteration Theory of Aging
theories.evidence: Gene expression data showed PTS-induced downregulation of ASF1B and GFI1B in rat blood. Prior studies cited link these genes to oncogenic effects and familial longevity. The paper discusses epigenetic regulation as a mechanism underlying phytoestrogen effects.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory addresses a fundamental aging hallmark (epigenetic alterations), proposes causal mechanisms through chromatin regulation, and links to organism-level aging processes, thus meeting criteria for an aging theory.

key_concepts.concept: Epigenetic alterations as a hallmark and driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Changes in chromatin structure and histone modifications regulate gene expression patterns that influence aging phenotypes and longevity.

key_concepts.concept: Downregulation of histone chaperones and transcriptional regulators
key_concepts.description: Reduced expression of ASF1B and GFI1B, which modulate chromatin and hematopoietic differentiation, may contribute to slowing aging by altering epigenetic states.

key_concepts.concept: Epigenetic mechanisms mediating phytoestrogen effects
key_concepts.description: Phytoestrogens like PTS can modulate epigenetic enzyme interactions with DNA, leading to gene expression changes that impact aging-related pathways.

theories.name: Inflammaging and Immunometabolic Regulation Theory of Aging
theories.evidence: RNA sequencing data from healthy rats fed pterostilbene (PTS)-supplemented diets showed differential expression of genes linked to reduced inflammation, altered macrophage polarization, enhanced autophagy, and metabolic regulation. Public human datasets showed age- and disease-associated expression changes in related genes. Prior literature on PTS, resveratrol, and dietary restriction supports these mechanisms.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory explains HOW aging occurs via chronic inflammation and immune-metabolic dysregulation at the organismal level, proposes causal mechanisms (macrophage polarization, autophagy, interferon signaling), and connects these to general aging hallmarks, thus meeting all core criteria for an aging theory.

key_concepts.concept: Chronic low-grade inflammation (inflammaging) as a driver of aging
key_concepts.description: Aging is accompanied by a persistent, low-level inflammatory state that disrupts immune and metabolic functions, contributing to systemic aging and age-related decline.

key_concepts.concept: Macrophage polarization shift from proinflammatory M1 to antiinflammatory M2 phenotypes
key_concepts.description: Age-related immune dysfunction involves increased M1 macrophages promoting inflammation; interventions that shift polarization toward M2 macrophages can reduce inflammation and potentially slow aging.

key_concepts.concept: Immunometabolism and autophagy regulation
key_concepts.description: Cellular metabolism changes, including ribosome biogenesis and mTOR signaling, influence immune cell activation and autophagy, which are critical for maintaining immune homeostasis and preventing age-related inflammation.

key_concepts.concept: Interferon signaling modulation
key_concepts.description: Downregulation of interferon-related genes reduces proinflammatory signaling, contributing to decreased immune activation and inflammaging.

key_concepts.concept: Dietary restriction mimicking via amino acid transporter downregulation
key_concepts.description: Reduced expression of amino acid transporters (e.g., Slc7a5) mimics dietary restriction, which is linked to increased longevity through enhanced autophagy and reduced mTOR activity.

title: Nuclear lamina defects cause ATM-dependent NF-κB activation and link accelerated aging to a systemic inflammatory response.

theories.name: Nuclear lamina defect-induced ATM-NEMO-dependent NF-κB activation theory of accelerated aging
theories.evidence: Experimental data from two progeroid mouse models (Zmpste24-/- and LmnaG609G/G609G) showing nuclear lamina defects lead to ATM activation, NEMO nuclear accumulation, NF-κB hyperactivation, and increased cytokine secretion; genetic reduction of NF-κB (RelA+/-) and pharmacological inhibition (sodium salicylate) extend lifespan and ameliorate aging phenotypes; human HGPS and aged donor fibroblasts show similar NF-κB activation patterns; transcriptomic analyses support NF-κB target gene upregulation.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all core criteria: generalizable mechanism linking nuclear lamina defects to systemic aging via inflammatory signaling; causal explanation through ATM-NEMO-NF-κB pathway; broad scope addressing systemic aging and inflammaging, not limited to single organ or disease; supported by mechanistic experiments and intervention studies.

key_concepts.concept: Nuclear lamina defects as aging initiators
key_concepts.description: Structural abnormalities in the nuclear envelope, specifically accumulation of prelamin A or progerin, cause genomic instability and activate DNA damage response pathways, serving as upstream triggers of aging-related cellular dysfunction.

key_concepts.concept: ATM and NEMO coordinate NF-κB activation
key_concepts.description: The DNA damage sensor ATM kinase and the regulatory protein NEMO cooperate to activate the NF-κB transcription factor in response to nuclear lamina defects, linking nuclear architecture abnormalities to inflammatory signaling.

key_concepts.concept: NF-κB hyperactivation drives systemic inflammation and aging phenotypes
key_concepts.description: Activated NF-κB induces secretion of proinflammatory cytokines (e.g., IL-6, CXCL1, TNF-α) establishing a chronic inflammatory state that contributes causally to accelerated aging phenotypes including tissue degeneration, immunosenescence, and reduced lifespan.

key_concepts.concept: Genetic and pharmacological inhibition of NF-κB extends lifespan and ameliorates aging features
key_concepts.description: Reducing NF-κB activity genetically (RelA haploinsufficiency) or pharmacologically (sodium salicylate treatment) in progeroid mouse models prevents age-associated tissue defects, reduces systemic inflammation, and significantly extends longevity, demonstrating causality.

key_concepts.concept: Senescent cell secretory phenotype (SASP) amplifies inflammation
key_concepts.description: Senescent cells accumulating due to nuclear lamina defects secrete inflammatory cytokines that reinforce NF-κB activation and systemic inflammation, creating a feed-forward loop that exacerbates aging-related pathology.

key_concepts.concept: Relevance to normal aging
key_concepts.description: Similar ATM-NEMO-dependent NF-κB activation and increased inflammatory cytokines are observed in normal aged tissues and cells, suggesting this pathway contributes broadly to physiological aging beyond progeroid syndromes.

title: Poly(ADP-ribosyl)ation and aging.

theories.name: Poly(ADP-ribosyl)ation-mediated DNA repair theory of aging
theories.evidence: Correlative data linking poly(ADP-ribosyl)ation capacity with longevity across species; recombinant enzyme comparisons; cell culture experiments manipulating PARP-1 activity showing effects on genomic instability; transgenic mouse models demonstrating PARP-1's role in suppressing skin carcinogenesis; literature on PARP-1 and WRN interaction.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain how aging occurs at the organism level by proposing that DNA damage accumulation drives aging and that poly(ADP-ribosyl)ation-mediated DNA repair modulates this process. It provides a causal mechanism (DNA repair capacity via PARP-1) that influences genomic stability and thus aging rate. The scope is broad, linking molecular mechanisms to species longevity and systemic aging processes, not limited to a single organ or disease.

key_concepts.concept: Poly(ADP-ribosyl)ation as a DNA damage response
key_concepts.description: Poly(ADP-ribosyl)ation is a post-translational modification catalyzed by PARP-1 in response to DNA strand breaks, facilitating DNA repair and promoting cell survival under genotoxic stress.

key_concepts.concept: Correlation between poly(ADP-ribosyl)ation capacity and species longevity
key_concepts.description: Higher poly(ADP-ribosyl)ation activity in mononuclear blood cells correlates positively with increased lifespan across mammalian species, suggesting a role in modulating aging rate.

key_concepts.concept: PARP-1 as a regulator of genomic stability
key_concepts.description: PARP-1 activity negatively regulates DNA damage-induced genomic instability, thereby reducing mutation accumulation and carcinogenesis, which are linked to aging.

key_concepts.concept: Evolutionary divergence of PARP-1
key_concepts.description: Differences in PARP-1 protein sequences between species may underlie variations in poly(ADP-ribosyl)ation capacity and thus influence species-specific longevity.

key_concepts.concept: Interaction with Werner syndrome protein (WRN)
key_concepts.description: PARP-1 physically and functionally interacts with WRN, a protein deficient in a premature aging syndrome, indicating a cooperative role in DNA repair pathways that affect aging.

title: Microglia in the aging brain: relevance to neurodegeneration.

theories.name: Microglia Senescence Theory of Aging-Related Neurodegeneration
theories.evidence: The paper reviews morphological studies showing dystrophic microglia in aged brains, telomere shortening in microglia, altered inflammatory profiles, gene expression changes in aged and AD microglia, and experimental models showing age-dependent microglia activation and neurotoxicity. It also cites human postmortem studies correlating microglia senescence with neurodegeneration.
theories.criteria_reasoning: The theory attempts to explain how aging causes a fundamental shift in microglia function that drives systemic brain aging and neurodegeneration, proposing causal mechanisms (senescence-induced dysfunction and over-activation). It is generalizable to organism-level brain aging and neurodegenerative diseases, not limited to a narrow phenomenon.

key_concepts.concept: Microglia senescence
key_concepts.description: Microglia, the brain's resident immune cells, undergo senescence with aging, characterized by morphological changes such as deramification, cytoplasmic beading, shortening and twisting of processes, and cytoplasmic fragmentation. This senescence impairs their normal neuroprotective functions.

key_concepts.concept: Switch from neuroprotective to neurotoxic function
key_concepts.description: In the young brain, microglia are neuroprotective, supporting neuronal survival and homeostasis. With aging and senescence, microglia become primed to overreact to stimuli, leading to over-activation and neurotoxicity that contributes to neurodegeneration.

key_concepts.concept: Intrinsic and extrinsic factors driving microglia dysfunction
key_concepts.description: Microglia dysfunction in aging may be caused by intrinsic factors such as telomere shortening and gene expression changes, or extrinsic factors including altered microenvironment, oxidative stress, neuroendocrine factors, and pathological protein aggregates like amyloid-beta.

key_concepts.concept: Microglia senescence as a causal driver of neurodegenerative diseases
key_concepts.description: Age-associated microglia senescence and over-activation contribute causally to the pathogenesis of Parkinson's disease and Alzheimer's disease by releasing excessive inflammatory cytokines and oxidative stress, leading to neuronal damage and degeneration.

title: Evidence for the role of selection for reproductively advantageous alleles in human aging.

theories.name: Antagonistic Pleiotropy Hypothesis of Aging
theories.evidence: Genome-wide analyses of 276,406 UK Biobank participants showing negative genetic correlations between reproductive traits and lifespan; polygenic scores for reproduction negatively predict survival to age 76; allele frequency increases of reproduction-enhancing variants over birth cohorts; eQTL analyses revealing cis-regulatory pleiotropy; statistical tests confirming excess antagonistic pleiotropy compared to random variants.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets all criteria: explains why aging occurs via evolutionary trade-offs at organism level; proposes causal mechanisms (pleiotropic mutations selected for reproduction but detrimental post-reproduction); generalizable beyond single organs or diseases; supported by genomic and evolutionary data.

key_concepts.concept: Pleiotropic mutations with early-life reproductive benefits
key_concepts.description: Mutations that increase reproductive success early in life can be favored by natural selection even if they have deleterious effects later in life, leading to aging as a trade-off.

key_concepts.concept: Negative genetic correlation between reproduction and lifespan
key_concepts.description: Genetic variants that promote reproduction tend to be associated with reduced lifespan, indicating antagonistic effects on these traits.

key_concepts.concept: Selective favoring of reproduction-enhancing alleles despite lifespan cost
key_concepts.description: Alleles that increase reproduction but reduce lifespan can increase in frequency over generations due to their reproductive advantage, demonstrating ongoing natural selection.

key_concepts.concept: Horizontal pleiotropy via cis-regulatory effects
key_concepts.description: Antagonistically pleiotropic variants often affect gene expression in multiple tissues or target multiple genes, influencing reproduction and lifespan through distinct molecular pathways.

theories.name: Disposable Soma Theory of Aging
theories.evidence: Mentioned as a potential biological explanation for antagonistic pleiotropy; supported by cross-species data showing inverse relationship between somatic mutation rate and lifespan.
theories.criteria_reasoning: Meets criteria as a general causal theory explaining aging via resource trade-offs; discussed in relation to findings but not directly tested or proposed in this paper.
